body: Can you reliably reproduce in a fresh folder and document exact steps to follow to repeat the issue?

Just tested, and yes, but needed an extra file:

 1. Make new file b in root of synced folder
 2. ln -s b a (still in root folder)
 2. Wait... wait... wait...
 3. Make new file c just for fun
 4. a gets deleted (maybe only after c was created?)

The "Latest change" though indicated "c" was updated only after "a" was deleted, so probably a herring.

I did the following with both the windows device (W) and linux on 0.14.50-rc.1:
1. On L: `echo foo > b && ln -s b a`
2. Wait, see b on W, not a obviously.
3. Keep waiting, nothing happens on L.
4. For good measure hit rescan on L, still the link stays there.
5. Create c on L, wait again, still a remains.

Is there anything you do differently?

Besides splitting 1 into two commands, no. This is **weird**. It is definitly syncthing deleting them too, since the change log explicitly says it!

Windows 10 and Debian 9 are the OSes. The syncthing version is `0.14.46+ds1-1`, so that may be the issue. Weirdly that's not the version they publish in the details of `stretch`. `sid` is at `14.49` but that would require 700 mb of upgrades and possibly breaking my machine.

It's windows 7 and debian testing here. Can you check whether you can reproduce with 49 or 50rc1 by either using apt.syncthing.net (which won't need to pull in any dependencies) or just by downloading the executable from github?
Also, make sure you can reproduce in a clean folder, not an existing one.
For some reason the two aren't connecting right now, I will try and get back to you both later on (hoping this is a connection thing that will fix itself).

New folder, save version - same thing. I now noticed the deletion "Latest change" only appears in the Linux machine that I created it on in the first place? Is there some configuration thing I'm missing? 

I'm getting the new version now.

So there is a global change log feature, if you could screenshot all changes to the symlink in question it would be interesting to see (ideally from both sides). I assume new folder is totally clean with no ignore patterns etc? 

You could also enable model debugging facility and post the logs from both sides for the link in question.

I'm not sure if it's the changed version, but now it's ignoring the first link in the same folder, but a new folder with a back link is being removed:

    echo b > b
    ln -s b a
    echo c > c
    mkdir bla
    ln -s b bla/abc

Two log pastes are below (I turned on fd,events,walkfs, and watchaggregator). Linux is explicitly saying it's deleting, and Windows is at least acknowledging it, but saying it's not found. The deleted link is `abc`, if you want to search for it in the mess below.

I know what's the problem here: With fine grained local flags instead of just one boolean the condition used when detecting deleted files isn't sufficient anymore:  
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/4952/files#diff-1df9805b2381b6288b220226f82d5dc9R2088
In this concrete example on windows: Symlink is marked as unsupported on pull. Then on scan `IsIgnored` is false, so the deletion check is performed, which is positive (there is no symlink) -> file info is wrongly marked as deleted. Yet another bug that passed unhindered through our longest RC phase ever to a stable release...

As to why I couldn't reproduce: My missing step was probably to scan on the windows side.

issue.title: lib/model: Fix regressions detecting deletes/ignores (fixes #5125, fixes #5127)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Ready for review - windows only test was verified to work and fix is now in place.  
<strike>**Do not merge**. This does not yet contain the fix for #5125, only the unit test that should reproduce it (<strike>i.e. if the new windows test passes, that's a failure</strike> it fails :) ).</strike>

### Purpose

When recurse unignoring (#4811), not only the scanner side of things should have been adapted, the model side of things (detecting ignores and deletes) as well.  
When adding more fine grained control over invalid files via local flags (#4952), the existing `IsIgnored` condition isn't enough anymore to filter files before checking whether they were deleted.

### Testing

Unit tests for both issues.

body: Great to hear you found it so easily, and great I could help. Thanks.

issue.title: Symbolic links gets deleted on Linux when Windows syncs back

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Setup

I **sync a directory between Linux and Windows 10**.
Versioning off, watching for changes enabled on both sides.

### What happened

When I **create a symlink on Linux**, and I wait for the **rescan** time (or I click rescan on Linux and then click rescan on Windows) the **symlink gets deleted on Linux side**.

The fact that the symlink doses not appear on Windows is expected, what is annoying is that it gets removed on Linux side when the Windows client syncs back.

### What was expected

The **symlink** created on Linux **should stay present on Linux**.

### For reproducing the bug

Sync a directory between Linux and Windows 10.
Create a symlink in the directory on Linux side.
Click on rescan button on Linux side.
Click on rescan button on Windows side.
Check if the symlink is still existing on Linux side.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version on Linux: v0.14.49 "Dysprosium Dragonfly" (go1.10.3 linux-amd64) builduser@svetlemodry 2018-07-29 16:37:02 UTC [noupgrade]

OS Version on Linux: Arch Linux

Syncthing Version on Windwos: v0.14.49 "Dysprosium Dragonfly" (go1.10.3 windows-amd64) teamcity@build.syncthing.net 2018-07-10 15:40:06 UTC

OS Version on Windows: Windows 10, version 1607, build 14393.1480

GUI on Windows: Synctrayzor 1.1.21
